title: Killing time in Munich with a plot against Hitler
text:
Tony Davis Motoring Writer Oct 10, 2019 — 11.41am Share

So what do you do when you’ve flown into Munich four hours before the start of a big automotive technical conference (hosted by BMW in its home city) that will almost certainly do your head in, and you’re thoroughly jet-lagged? You go looking for sites of anti-Nazi resistance. Well, of course you do.

Munich was a place of great significance for the guys in the Hugo Boss uniforms and shiny boots. There was, for example, the Munich Agreement of 1938, which didn’t quite give us “peace for our time” as promised by then British leader Neville Chamberlain, and the Bürgerbräukeller beer hall, where Herr A. Hitler had his first tilt at power in 1923 with a putsch. But, of much more interest, Munich is also where two very bold moves were made against the Nazis.

A rainy-day snapshot of Munich's Marienplatz in 1939.

The Bürgerbräukeller was pulled down in the late 1970s, and replaced by the Gasteig cultural centre. Hidden in that complex is something strange and inspiring in equal measure. But after walking around for a quarter of an hour to the sounds of violins being tuned somewhere inside the network of buildings, I couldn’t find it.

I eventually asked a ticket seller. He happily jumped up, left his glass booth and walked me towards a rather grotesque 1980s sculpture in the courtyard. There it was, just beyond: a large bronze plaque in the cobblestones paying tribute to a man who tried to assassinate a head of state – and killed eight others in the botched process.

His name was Georg Elser. He was a 36-year-old carpenter with a penchant for playing the zither. And in 1939 he single-handedly hatched a plan to blow up the Bürgerbräukeller when Hitler, now successfully installed as Führer, returned to commemorate the anniversary of the Beer Hall Putsch.

Zither player and would-be assassin Georg Elser: but for the weather, he could have rewritten 20th-century history. Getty

Over 30-plus nights, Elser snuck in after closing time and hollowed out a column next to the stage. He inserted a time-bomb, surrounded by cork to muffle the ticking. Elser later explained that he “wanted to stop the war”.

There was nothing to do but stare and reflect on how many things would have changed for the better if not for those 13 minutes.

The bomb was set for 9.20pm, November 8, but due to bad weather Hitler changed his arrangements and missed being blown up by 13 minutes. Elser was captured at the Swiss border and eventually executed in 1945, a month before the end of World War II; Hitler saw his own escape as divine providence (as narcissists do).
description: Learning about the White Rose resistance movement and a plan to assassinate the Nazi leader is one way to fill in spare hours in the Bavarian capital.
